channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Thrilling volcanoes, astonishing beetles and numbers made material: Books in brief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03357-z

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
item.dc:title: Thrilling volcanoes, astonishing beetles and numbers made material: Books in brief
item.dc:creator: Andrew Robinson

item.title: How big quantum computers could keep their qubits under control
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03280-3

Multitasking electrodes could enable 1,000 qubits to fit onto one device.
item.dc:title: How big quantum computers could keep their qubits under control

item.title: Menopausal chimpanzees deepen the mystery of why women stop reproducing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03308-8

Some chimpanzees have been found to experience menopause. But are they the exception or the rule?
item.dc:title: Menopausal chimpanzees deepen the mystery of why women stop reproducing
item.dc:creator: Dyani Lewis

item.title: Daily briefing: A unique layer of molten rock envelops Mars’s core
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03356-0

Mars has a surprise layer around its liquid-metal core. Plus, the editor of a prominent journal is fired in wake of Israel–Hamas remarks and an AI that has human-like ability to generalize language.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: A unique layer of molten rock envelops Mars’s core
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Scientists call out rogue emissions from China at global ozone summit
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03325-7

Researchers confirm a powerful greenhouse gas being emitted from eastern China despite reports to the contrary.
item.dc:title: Scientists call out rogue emissions from China at global ozone summit
item.dc:creator: Jeff Tollefson

item.title: How robots can learn to follow a moral code
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03258-1

Ethical artificial intelligence aims to impart human values on machine-learning systems.
item.dc:title: How robots can learn to follow a moral code
item.dc:creator: Neil Savage

item.title: Heavy element production in a compact object merger observed by JWST
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06759-1

Heavy element production in a compact object merger observed by JWST
item.dc:title: Heavy element production in a compact object merger observed by JWST

item.title: TMPRSS2 is a functional receptor for human coronavirus HKU1
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06761-7

TMPRSS2 is a functional receptor for human coronavirus HKU1
item.dc:title: TMPRSS2 is a functional receptor for human coronavirus HKU1

item.title: A superconducting nanowire single-photon camera with 400,000 pixels
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06550-2

The development of a 400,000-pixel superconducting nanowire single-photon detector array is described, improving the current state of the art by a factor of 400 and showing scalability well beyond the present demonstration.
item.dc:title: A superconducting nanowire single-photon camera with 400,000 pixels
item.dc:creator: B. G. Oripov
D. S. Rampini
J. Allmaras
M. D. Shaw
S. W. Nam
B. Korzh
A. N. McCaughan

item.title: Interface design for all-solid-state lithium batteries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06653-w

The inclusion of a Mg–Bi-based interlayer between the lithium metal and solid electrolyte and a F-rich interlayer on the cathode improves the stability and performance of solid-state lithium-metal batteries.
item.dc:title: Interface design for all-solid-state lithium batteries
item.dc:creator: Hongli Wan
Zeyi Wang
Weiran Zhang
Xinzi He
Chunsheng Wang

item.title: On-surface synthesis of a doubly anti-aromatic carbon allotrope
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06566-8

The carbon allotrope cyclo[16]carbon has been synthesized using on-surface chemistry and characterized with scanning tunnelling microscopy and atomic force microscopy, revealing orbital densities and bond-length alternation, which show it to be doubly anti-aromatic.
item.dc:title: On-surface synthesis of a doubly anti-aromatic carbon allotrope
item.dc:creator: Yueze Gao
Florian Albrecht
Igor Rončević

Luca Righetti
Max Rossmannek
Ivano Tavernelli

Leo Gross

item.title: Normative spatiotemporal fetal brain maturation with satisfactory development at 2 years
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06630-3

A normative digital atlas of fetal brain maturation produced using 1,059 optimal quality, three-dimensional ultrasound brain volumes from 899 fetuses presents a unique spatiotemporal benchmark from a large cohort with normative postnatal growth and neurodevelopment at 2 years of age.
item.dc:title: Normative spatiotemporal fetal brain maturation with satisfactory development at 2 years
item.dc:creator: Ana I. L. Namburete

item.title: An ON-type direction-selective ganglion cell in primate retina
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06659-4

Transcriptomic data and functional experiments on macaque retina are used to identify the ON-type direction-selective ganglion cells responsible for detecting moving images and initiating gaze-stabilization mechanisms.
item.dc:title: An ON-type direction-selective ganglion cell in primate retina
item.dc:creator: Anna Y. M. Wang
Manoj M. Kulkarni
Amanda J. McLaughlin
Jacqueline Gayet
Benjamin E. Smith

Yvette Y. Yao
Teresa Puthussery

item.title: Dipolar quantum solids emerging in a Hubbard quantum simulator
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06614-3

The realization of dipolar quantum solids with an ultracold gas of magnetic atoms in an optical lattice ushers in quantum simulation of many-body systems with long-range anisotropic interactions.
item.dc:title: Dipolar quantum solids emerging in a Hubbard quantum simulator
item.dc:creator: Lin Su
Alexander Douglas
Michal Szurek

Aaron Krahn

Markus Greiner

item.title: Remarkable heat conduction mediated by non-equilibrium phonon polaritons
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06598-0

Measurements of thermal transport along 3C-SiC nanowires with and without a gold coating on the end(s) suggest that thermally excited surface phonon polaritons can be used in nanostructures to substantially enhance thermal conductivity.
item.dc:title: Remarkable heat conduction mediated by non-equilibrium phonon polaritons
item.dc:creator: Zhiliang Pan
Guanyu Lu
Xun Li
James R. McBride
Rinkle Juneja
Mackey Long
Lucas Lindsay
Joshua D. Caldwell
Deyu Li

item.title: Evidence for a liquid silicate layer atop the Martian core
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06586-4

Using multiply diffracted P waves and first-principles computations of the thermoelastic properties of liquid iron-rich alloys, we show that the core of Mars is smaller and denser than previously thought.
item.dc:title: Evidence for a liquid silicate layer atop the Martian core
item.dc:creator: A. Khan
D. Huang
C. Durán
P. A. Sossi
D. Giardini
M. Murakami

item.title: Structure and electromechanical coupling of a voltage-gated Na<sup>+</sup>/H<sup>+</sup> exchanger
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06518-2

Upon hyperpolarization, the S4 voltage-sensing segment of sea urchin SLC9C1 moves down, removing inhibition caused by an intracellular helix and enabling Na+/H+ exchange, leading to pH-dependent activation of sAC and sperm chemotaxis.
item.dc:title: Structure and electromechanical coupling of a voltage-gated Na<sup>+</sup>/H<sup>+</sup> exchanger
item.dc:creator: Hyunku Yeo
Ved Mehta
Ashutosh Gulati
David Drew

item.title: All-analog photoelectronic chip for high-speed vision tasks
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06558-8

An all-analog chip combining electronic and light computing achieves systemic energy efficiency of more than three orders of magnitude and a computing speed of more than one order of magnitude compared with state-of-the-art computing processors.
item.dc:title: All-analog photoelectronic chip for high-speed vision tasks
item.dc:creator: Yitong Chen
Maimaiti Nazhamaiti
Han Xu
Yao Meng
Tiankuang Zhou
Guangpu Li
Jingtao Fan
Qi Wei
Jiamin Wu
Fei Qiao
Lu Fang
Qionghai Dai

item.title: Disruption of sugar nucleotide clearance is a therapeutic vulnerability of cancer cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06676-3

An enzyme called UXS1 that converts one sugar nucleotide to another is needed more in some cancer cells than in normal cells, providing a potential weakness that can be exploited therapeutically.
item.dc:title: Disruption of sugar nucleotide clearance is a therapeutic vulnerability of cancer cells
item.dc:creator: Mihir B. Doshi
Namgyu Lee

item.title: Structures of a sperm-specific solute carrier gated by voltage and cAMP
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06629-w

This study proposes a molecular mechanism of voltage activation in SLC9C1, a transporter essential for male fertility.
item.dc:title: Structures of a sperm-specific solute carrier gated by voltage and cAMP
item.dc:creator: Valeria Kalienkova
Martin F. Peter
Jan Rheinberger
Cristina Paulino

item.title: Dopaminergic systems create reward seeking despite adverse consequences
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06671-8

In Drosophila, a subpopulation of reward-encoding dopaminergic neurons antagonizes punishment-encoding neurons and can override punishment or hunger cues in favour of reward-seeking behaviour.
item.dc:title: Dopaminergic systems create reward seeking despite adverse consequences
item.dc:creator: Kristijan D. Jovanoski
Lucille Duquenoy
Jessica Mitchell
Ishaan Kapoor
Christoph D. Treiber

Nils Otto

Scott Waddell

item.title: Leishmania genetic exchange is mediated by IgM natural antibodies
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06655-8

Genetic exchange of Leishmania parasites in the sand fly host is mediated by natural IgM antibodies, providing insights that will help generate reproducible and increased recovery of backcrosses for research purposes.
item.dc:title: Leishmania genetic exchange is mediated by IgM natural antibodies
item.dc:creator: Tiago D. Serafim
Eva Iniguez
Ana Beatriz F. Barletta

item.title: On the origin of diffuse intensities in fcc electron diffraction patterns
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06530-6

Some of the diffuse intensities observed in electron diffraction patterns of face-centred cubic multi-principal element alloys are due to reflections from higher-order Laue zones.
item.dc:title: On the origin of diffuse intensities in fcc electron diffraction patterns
item.dc:creator: Francisco Gil Coury
Cody Miller
Robert Field
Michael Kaufman

item.title: A single photoreceptor splits perception and entrainment by cotransmission
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06681-6

The Drosophila R8 photoreceptor separates signals for image perception and circadian photoentrainment by co-releasing histamine and acetylcholine, and this segregation is further established in the postsynaptic circuitry in the medulla.
item.dc:title: A single photoreceptor splits perception and entrainment by cotransmission
item.dc:creator: Na Xiao
Shuang Xu

Renbo Mao

Dong-Gen Luo

item.title: Assessing the illegal hunting of native wildlife in China
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06625-0

Analysis of a database of convictions for illegal hunting in China reveals the scale of the threat to biodiversity posed by illegal hunting in China.
item.dc:title: Assessing the illegal hunting of native wildlife in China
item.dc:creator: Dan Liang
Xingli Giam
Sifan Hu
Liang Ma
David S. Wilcove

item.title: Geophysical evidence for an enriched molten silicate layer above Mars’s core
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06601-8

We provide observational evidence that suggests the presence of a molten silicate layer above the core of Mars, which is overlain by a partially molten layer, indicating that the core of Mars is smaller than previously thought.
item.dc:title: Geophysical evidence for an enriched molten silicate layer above Mars’s core
item.dc:creator: Henri Samuel
Mélanie Drilleau

William B. Banerdt

item.title: A microfluidic transistor for automatic control of liquids
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06517-3

Flow limitation is exploited to develop a microfluidic device exhibiting flow–pressure behaviour analogous to the current–voltage characteristics of an electronic transistor.
item.dc:title: A microfluidic transistor for automatic control of liquids
item.dc:creator: Kaustav A. Gopinathan
Avanish Mishra
Baris R. Mutlu
Jon F. Edd
Mehmet Toner

item.title: Human-like systematic generalization through a meta-learning neural network
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06668-3

The meta-learning for compositionality approach achieves the systematicity and flexibility needed for human-like generalization.
item.dc:title: Human-like systematic generalization through a meta-learning neural network
item.dc:creator: Brenden M. Lake
Marco Baroni

item.title: How light receptor cells in fruit-fly eyes multitask
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03268-z

A type of light-sensitive cell in one of the visual systems of fruit flies transmits two chemical messengers, histamine and acetylcholine, in response to the same light signal. These two molecules act on distinct neurons that have different functions: one type creates an image and the other synchronizes biological rhythms with the day–night cycle.
item.dc:title: How light receptor cells in fruit-fly eyes multitask

item.title: African researchers’ work is being overlooked — here’s how to change that
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03322-w

The continent’s scientists see opportunities in international collaborations that are rooted in Africa, rather than originating in Europe and North America.
item.dc:title: African researchers’ work is being overlooked — here’s how to change that
item.dc:creator: Munyaradzi Makoni

item.title: Convictions show scale of wildlife hunting in China
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02942-6

An analysis of convictions reveals that around one-fifth of China’s terrestrial vertebrate species were illegally hunted over a six-year period. Improved efforts to reduce such crimes are needed to control this threat to biodiversity.
item.dc:title: Convictions show scale of wildlife hunting in China
item.dc:creator: David P. Edwards

item.title: Staring at the Sun — close-up images from space rewrite solar science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03301-1

Researchers have never had such detailed views of our nearest star.
item.dc:title: Staring at the Sun — close-up images from space rewrite solar science
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: Daily briefing: Postdocs in their thirties express unhappiness with careers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03344-4

Postdocs in their thirties are less happy in their careers, overall, than are their peers in their twenties. Plus, ancient rock carvings exposed by severe drought and how the Israel–Hamas war affects scientists.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Postdocs in their thirties express unhappiness with careers
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Large-scale nanowire camera with a single-photon sensitivity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02797-x

Superconducting detectors are a leading technology for the detection of single photons, but have been limited in the number of pixels that they can offer. A 400,000-pixel superconducting nanowire single-photon detector camera provides an improvement by a factor of 400 compared with the current state of the art.
item.dc:title: Large-scale nanowire camera with a single-photon sensitivity

item.title: Dopamine determines how reward overrides risk
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03085-4

Why do animals pursue reward in the face of punishment? Dopamine-releasing neurons that promote reward-seeking behaviour indirectly impair those that encode punishment avoidance, affecting decisions on risk.
item.dc:title: Dopamine determines how reward overrides risk
item.dc:creator: Kristin M. Scaplen
Karla R. Kaun

item.title: Mars has a surprise layer of molten rock inside
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03271-4

Fresh investigations find that the red planet’s liquid-metal core is smaller than scientists thought.
item.dc:title: Mars has a surprise layer of molten rock inside
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: Japanese research is no longer world class — here’s why
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03290-1

Despite a strong workforce, Japan’s research continues to slide down the indicators of quality.
item.dc:title: Japanese research is no longer world class — here’s why
item.dc:creator: Anna Ikarashi

item.title: ‘I’m a powder keg’: ousted eLife editor on being fired in wake of Israel–Hamas remarks
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03330-w

Debate rages in scientific community over Michael Eisen’s removal from prominent open-access journal.
item.dc:title: ‘I’m a powder keg’: ousted eLife editor on being fired in wake of Israel–Hamas remarks
item.dc:creator: Nicola Jones

item.title: Deep Mars is surprisingly soft
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03151-x

Two analyses of seismic waves that traversed Mars paint the clearest picture yet of the red planet’s core and deep mantle — and rationalize the puzzling implications of a previous interpretation of the seismological data.
item.dc:title: Deep Mars is surprisingly soft
item.dc:creator: Suzan van der Lee

item.title: An ion transporter in sperm that has features of a channel
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03154-8

A membrane-transport protein in sperm exchanges sodium and hydrogen ions. Its activations by voltage and by cyclic nucleotide molecules are usually only features of ion channels. Structural data shed light on this protein.
item.dc:title: An ion transporter in sperm that has features of a channel
item.dc:creator: John Orlowski

item.title: Forward, backward
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03305-x

Simpler times.
item.dc:title: Forward, backward
item.dc:creator: Nayani Jensen

item.title: AI ‘breakthrough’: neural net has human-like ability to generalize language
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03272-3

A neural-network-based artificial intelligence outperforms ChatGPT at quickly folding new words into its lexicon, a key aspect of human intelligence.
item.dc:title: AI ‘breakthrough’: neural net has human-like ability to generalize language
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov
Celeste Biever

item.title: Sounds of recovery: AI helps monitor wildlife during forest restoration
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03329-3

System aids researchers measuring biodiversity levels in Ecuador, and how people can follow basic instructions while fast asleep.
item.dc:title: Sounds of recovery: AI helps monitor wildlife during forest restoration
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Shamini Bundell

item.title: Magnetic atoms push interactions to new lengths for quantum simulation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03152-w

Lasers, and a cold ensemble of magnetic atoms, have been used to mimic a complex quantum system characterized by long-range interactions — an essential ingredient for realizing realistic models of many quantum materials.
item.dc:title: Magnetic atoms push interactions to new lengths for quantum simulation
item.dc:creator: P. Blair Blakie
Barbara Capogrosso-Sansone

item.title: Computer vision accelerated using photons and electrons
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02947-1

A single chip that integrates optical and electronic analog computing modules provides a strategy for creating all-analog computing processors with a speed and energy efficiency that are several orders of magnitude higher than those of state-of-the-art digital processors.
item.dc:title: Computer vision accelerated using photons and electrons

item.title: Britain and Ireland’s largest lake is dying in plain sight
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03313-x

Britain and Ireland’s largest lake is dying in plain sight
item.dc:title: Britain and Ireland’s largest lake is dying in plain sight
item.dc:creator: Neil Reid
Mark C. Emmerson

item.title: From the archive: soap success, and Michael Faraday’s lecture tips
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03158-4

Snippets from Nature’s past.
item.dc:title: From the archive: soap success, and Michael Faraday’s lecture tips

item.title: Extreme drought is again isolating people in Amazonia
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03311-z

Extreme drought is again isolating people in Amazonia
item.dc:title: Extreme drought is again isolating people in Amazonia
item.dc:creator: Letícia Santos de Lima

item.title: Give these ‘living composite’ objects a squeeze and watch them glow
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03279-w

A material made from tiny algae and a natural polymer can be 3D printed into a variety of shapes.
item.dc:title: Give these ‘living composite’ objects a squeeze and watch them glow

item.title: Quantify wild areas that optimize agricultural yields
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03312-y

Quantify wild areas that optimize agricultural yields
item.dc:title: Quantify wild areas that optimize agricultural yields
item.dc:creator: Iris Berger
Lynn V. Dicks
Francisco d’Albertas Gomes de Carvalho

item.title: Daily briefing: Severe COVID linked to bad fungal microbiome
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03327-5

An imbalance of fungi in the gut could contribute to excessive inflammation in people with severe COVID-19. Plus, mummified mice reveal mammals’ unexpected survival skills and the Moon could be 40 million years older than we thought.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Severe COVID linked to bad fungal microbiome
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: China’s Belt and Road Initiative is boosting science — the West must engage, not withdraw
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03299-6

China is deepening scientific links with low- and middle-income countries. Europe and the United States would be wise to join this effort, which could help to resolve economic, environmental and political crises.
item.dc:title: China’s Belt and Road Initiative is boosting science — the West must engage, not withdraw

item.title: Assessing the scale of rubber deforestation in southeast Asia
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03153-9

Understanding the extent of deforestation associated with agriculturally harvested crops has implications for conservation efforts. A method to assess satellite data offers an accurate way to estimate rubber deforestation.
item.dc:title: Assessing the scale of rubber deforestation in southeast Asia
item.dc:creator: Carlos Souza Jr

item.title: Anti-COVID drug accelerates viral evolution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03248-3

Molnupiravir, an antiviral drug used to treat COVID-19, induces numerous mutations in the SARS-CoV-2 genome that can increase the rate at which the virus evolves — yielding viral variants that might survive and be passed on.
item.dc:title: Anti-COVID drug accelerates viral evolution
item.dc:creator: Sergei L. Kosakovsky Pond
Darren Martin

item.title: An AI revolution is brewing in medicine. What will it look like?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03302-0

Emerging generalist models could overcome some limitations of first-generation machine-learning tools for clinical use.
item.dc:title: An AI revolution is brewing in medicine. What will it look like?
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: Why I use Notion to organize my PhD research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03323-9

Maya Gosztyla describes the database tool as a ‘second brain’, helping her to coordinate her work.
item.dc:title: Why I use Notion to organize my PhD research
item.dc:creator: Maya Gosztyla

item.title: Gordon Conway (1938–2023), leader in sustainable development
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03321-x

Agricultural ecologist who promoted sustainable practices by engaging farmers worldwide.
item.dc:title: Gordon Conway (1938–2023), leader in sustainable development
item.dc:creator: Ian Scoones

item.title: Scientists in diaspora are a powerful resource for their home countries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03300-2

Networks of émigré researchers can be potent forces for good when they are member-driven, involve youth and connect with each other.
item.dc:title: Scientists in diaspora are a powerful resource for their home countries
item.dc:creator: Rana Dajani

item.title: Postdocs are pushing back against low pay and conditions — more institutions must take heed
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03298-7

Postdoctoral dissatisfaction about pay, job security and career progression cannot continue. Institutions must up their game or risk losing the next generation.
item.dc:title: Postdocs are pushing back against low pay and conditions — more institutions must take heed

item.title: Falling behind: postdocs in their thirties tire of putting life on hold
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03296-9

Temporary contracts, low salaries and cost-of-living hikes force many researchers to put off parenthood and other big decisions.
item.dc:title: Falling behind: postdocs in their thirties tire of putting life on hold
item.dc:creator: Linda Nordling

item.title: Ancient DNA reveals traces of elusive first humans in Europe
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03278-x

Europe’s earliest Homo sapiens seemed to have vanished without a genetic legacy — but genomic studies now show otherwise.
item.dc:title: Ancient DNA reveals traces of elusive first humans in Europe

item.title: I tread the delicate line between culture and conservation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03304-y

Ethno-ecologist Nolwazi Mbongwa investigates the deeply rooted cultural practices of South African traditional healers, and works with conservationists to protect wildlife.
item.dc:title: I tread the delicate line between culture and conservation
item.dc:creator: Linda Nordling

item.title: Fierce ferns make insect-fighting proteins
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03281-2

Natural compounds could help to protect maize and soya beans against pests that have evolved resistance to conventional insecticides.
item.dc:title: Fierce ferns make insect-fighting proteins

item.title: Mysterious mouse mummies found atop lofty volcanoes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03282-1

Naturally freeze-dried leaf-eared mice found above 6,000 metres show mammals can dwell at extraordinary heights.
item.dc:title: Mysterious mouse mummies found atop lofty volcanoes
item.dc:creator: Anil Oza

item.title: The plant poisons that shape our daily lives
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03303-z

An exploration of nature’s toxins reveals complex relationships between humans and the plant chemicals we use as foods, medicines and mind-altering drugs.
item.dc:title: The plant poisons that shape our daily lives
item.dc:creator: Emily Monosson

item.title: Grand plan to drought-proof India could reduce rainfall
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03193-1

The major engineering scheme aims to interlink several Indian rivers to support irrigation.
item.dc:title: Grand plan to drought-proof India could reduce rainfall
item.dc:creator: Rishika Pardikar

item.title: Daily briefing: Why women were deliberately infected with Zika
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03320-y

The first study to deliberately infect people with Zika virus suggests that this strategy could help to test vaccines. Plus, a gigantic plan to link India’s rivers could reduce rainfall in already arid regions and how scientists are studying the evolution of the city mouse.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Why women were deliberately infected with Zika
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Inflammation in severe COVID linked to bad fungal microbiome
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03295-w

An overabundant ‘mycobiota’ in the gut might be involved in triggering harmful immune responses.
item.dc:title: Inflammation in severe COVID linked to bad fungal microbiome
item.dc:creator: McKenzie Prillaman

item.title: Scientists deliberately gave women Zika — here’s why
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03289-8

‘Human challenge’ results suggest that such trials could be used to test vaccines when Zika incidence is low.
item.dc:title: Scientists deliberately gave women Zika — here’s why
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: Toxic workplaces are the main reason women leave academic jobs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03251-8

Women feel driven out by problems with workplace culture more often than by lack of work–life balance.
item.dc:title: Toxic workplaces are the main reason women leave academic jobs
item.dc:creator: Saima Sidik

item.title: Campus surveillance: students and professors decry sensors in buildings
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03287-w

Privacy campaigners fear that the devices could be used for disciplinary purposes, and some universities have deactivated them after protests.
item.dc:title: Campus surveillance: students and professors decry sensors in buildings
item.dc:creator: Anne Gulland
Fayth Tan
